newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: PRESS DIGEST - NZ BUSINESS WEEKLIES - AUG 8.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - NZ BUSINESS WEEKLIES - AUG 8.

text.p: THE INDEPENDENT BUSINESS WEEKLY
Greenies threaten Ceramco: Environmental activists within the Department of Conservation are threatening the lifeblood of Ceramco -- a major, publicly-listed company. Page 1.

IRD locks liquidators out of gov't work: A row is brewing among Auckland insolvency practitioners about a government decision to lock them out of court-ordered Inland Revenue Department company liquidations for the next year. Page 1.

Airline's money went west: John Vague and Graeme McDonald, the liquidators for collapsed Auckland-based Central Pacific Airlines, on Thursday formally ordered the chief executive of an Australian airline charter company to front up in their Auckland offices for a formal, financial examination. Page 1.

Dairy Board troubles sour Meat Board's future: While a parliamentary select committee considers legislation to reform the Meat Board, questions are being raised in trade policy circles about who should manage meat quota. Page 2.

Apple Fields to quit Rural Super Bonds: Fund manager and former orchardist Apple Fields is tipped to close its two Rural Super Bonds superannuation funds -- worth a combined $54 million -- and replace them with mortgage-backed debenture stock. Page 4.

CHH criticises ECNZ carve-up: Carter Holt Harvey boss John Faraci on Thursday criticised the government's handling of electricity deregulation after noting power costs at the company's Kinleith pulp and paper mill had risen 22 percent in the last year. Page 4.

Curtains for Kirton: Associate Health Minister Neil Kirton, sacked by his New Zealand First leader, Winston Peters, says his radio interview was a smokescreen for the real reasons for his removal. Page 4.

Gossips promo TVNZ departures: For weeks, rumours, all vigorously denied by TVNZ, presaged the imminent departure of a number of senior corporate executives -- including chief executive Chris Anderson. Page 5.

Clocked car crusader battles against bankruptcy: Clocked car crusader Dermot Nottingham will next week try to have thrown out a bankruptcy proceeding relating to a $240,000 debt claimed by defunct contributory mortgage company Registered Securities Ltd. Page 6.

Judge queries Power NZ's power play: Seeking to prevent Power NZ and its five foundation directors from taking steps, as it puts it, to "unilaterally expropriate" its $290 million stake in Power NZ, Utilicorp was this week granted an interim injunction, preventing its 31 percent shareholding from being sold without its consent. Page 8.
THE NATIONAL BUSINESS REVIEW
Bolger buys time as Kirton goes: The sacking of Associate Health Minister Neil Kirton has averted an immediate challenge to Prime Minister Jim Bolger's leadership. Page 1.
Black Magic goes galactic: Team New Zealand's rout of its competition in winning the America's Cup is having huge influence in the US -- off the water and even into space. Page 1.

Trade bill angers manufacturers: The Manufacturers' Federation is fuming about legislation due to go before Parliament on Tuesday, which would give Australian exporters a head start in trans-tasman trade. Page 2.

Police retreat behind wall of silence on computer scheme: Police have imposed a blanket media ban on the Incis project as they admit uncertainty over the latest deadline to connect up their new network, which is already running almost a year behind schedule. Page 2.
Telstra hangs out on deal: Telstra New Zealand says it does not have an agreement with BellSouth on the use of its cellphone spectrum licence. Page 3.

$2.8m payout for Tower investors: Tower Trust Services has received news that $2.8 million in compensation money for 1500 of its investors caught up in a UK funds management scandal may be close to delivery. Page 3.

Boiling point reached at TVNZ: TVNZ director of television Neil Roberts is feeling political heat from the Beehive after his bitter boardroom standoff with departing chief executive Chris Anderson and is unlikely to get the top job. Page 3.
TAB cleans up after a punt on sports betting: New Zealand's first year of sports betting has pushed the turnover of the new-look TAB past $1 billion for its third successive record turnover. Page 6.
